column11: Photo caption

column7: The bandleader, composer and radio and TV host wrote "Willie And The Hand Jive" and discovered many of R&B's greatest voices.
column10: Charlie Gillett Collection/Redferns Via Getty Images
column11: Johnny Otis (center), shown playing with his band The Johnny Otis Revue.

column7: The “At Last” singer had grit in her voice that could melt like sugar or rub salt in a wound.
column11: Etta James rehearses a song before recording at Fame Studios circa 1967 in Muscle Shoals, Ala.

column7: His show proved that undiluted black culture, expressed unapologetically, could become mainstream.
column11: In this television still, Aretha Franklin sings next to Cornelius.

column7: One of the world’s biggest-selling artists during a heyday that stretched from the mid-1980s through the late ‘90s and included such massive hits as “How Will I Know,” “I Wanna Dance With Somebody (Who Loves Me)” and “I Will Always Love You.”
column11: Whitney Houston performs in 1988.

column7: The actor-turned-teen idol made his name as part of the made-for-TV band in the 1960s.
column11: Davy Jones in 1968

column7: For more than 50 years, “the world’s oldest teenager” was one of pop culture’s most familiar figures.
column11: Dick Clark hosts American Bandstand in 1958.

column6: Drummer and Singer in The Band.
column7: Helm played superpowered, shifting backbeats, helped Bob Dylan go electric and sang some of The Band’s biggest hits, including “The Weight” and “Up On Cripple Creek.”
column11: Levon Helm performing with The Band in 1971.

column7: Even when his group was at its silliest, Yauch’s low, hoarse voice made him seem like the most mature member of the Beastie Boys. Over a career that went in many directions, from political advocate to filmmaker, he earned the title.
column11: MCA (center) with Mike D and Ad-Rock in New York City in 1994

column7: As one-fourth of Booker T. & the M.G.s, Dunn helped lay the foundation for Memphis Soul.
column11: Donald "Duck" Dunn onstage about 1990.

column7: Everyone from Eric B. and Rakim to Duran Duran sampled his music. Go-go eventually fell off the charts, but it never fell out of favor in D.C., Brown’s home town. Throw your hands up!
column11: Chuck Brown (with guitar) leads his band in 1978.

column7: Summer created dozens of hits, including “Love To Love You Baby” and “Bad Girls.” Over five decades, she combined a light touch, innovative sounds and an attention to detail that made her one of pop’s best performers.
column11: Donna Summer performs in Atlanta in 1978.

column7: Unmatched among classical song interpreters for his lyricism and sensitivity, Fischer-Dieskau was called “a born god who has it all” by fellow legend Elizabeth Schwarzkopf.
column11: German baritone Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau performing in England in 1962.

column7: Robin called himself the shyest of the three Gibb brothers. He came across as the most serious Bee Gee and many of the songs on which he sings lead have a melancholy tone.
column11: Robin Gibb, of The Bee Gees, performing at the London Palladium, 1969.

column7: The blind folk musician from North Carolina revolutionized how people play guitar as well as the way the world thinks about mountain music.
column11: American blues, folk, and country musician Doc Watson (born Arthel Lane Watson) in the 1960s
column22: Charlie Louvin, "See The Big Man Cry"

column7: Wells sang about the real problems of postwar life and the sad side of domesticity.
column11: Kitty Wells in the 1950s.
column13: "It Wasn't God Who Made Honky Tonk Angels"

column7: She was a cultural icon across the Spanish-speaking world, with a voice that redefined notions of beauty and an attitude that brashly bent gender roles.
column11: Chavela Vargas performs in Peru in 2002 at age 83.

column7: He wrote music for The Sting, A Chorus Line and The Way We Were and won Emmys, Grammys, Oscars and a Tony award.
column10: Time & Life Pictures/Time Life Pictures/Getty Images
column11: Marvin Hamlisch (left) with Liza Minnelli and Barry Manilow in 1987.
column13: "What I Did For Love" from 'A Chorus Line'

column7: The tenorist was an icon in his home town’s jazz community and among aficionados worldwide.
column11: Von Freeman performs in Amsterdam in 1983.

column7: As a teenager he carried records for DJs. As a professional, he carried water for an industry and for a culture.
column11: Chris Lighty with party guests in 2004.
column13: "What" performed by A Tribe Called Quest

column7: David is best known for his many collaborations with composer Burt Bacharach between the late 1950s and the mid-‘70s.
column11: Hal David in a 1962 recording session with Dionne Warwick and Burt Bacharach.
column13: "Raindrops Keep Fallin' On My Head" performed by BJ Thomas

column7: The clean-cut crooner and TV host had 18 gold albums. His hits that stretched from the '60s into the '90s.
column11: Andy Williams performing.

column7: The winner of two Pulitzer Prizes, the composer wrote acidic and witty music championed by the likes of Daniel Barenboim, Pierre Boulez and Yo-Yo Ma.
column11: Composer Elliott Carter.

column7: One of the most recognized and recognizable musicians of the postwar era, he made “Take Five” into a pop hit.
column11: Dave Brubeck (at the piano) with The Dave Brubeck Quartet.

column7: The Mexican –American singer was a household name and feminist presence in the Latin music world.
column11: Singer Jenni Rivera at the 11th annual Latin GRAMMY Awards in 2010.

column7: He played with Yehudi Menuhin, George Harrison and Philip Glass and influenced a world of musicians.
column11: Ravi Shankar playing the sitar in May 1966.
